takes you to uh to sort of establish a N Net Connection um means that you really
want to limit the number of times you're making HTTP connections up to your server you want to kind of create one HTTP connection and then try to send a
lot of data back and forth on it so the the concept of sort of uh Comet based connections or long polling connections
that type of stuff has been around for a long time but in the process-based model that we talked about before that means I
would have to have a dedicated process or thread tied up holding that socket open um and that actually causes some
big problems because eventually as you start to scale up that means every one of your users is taking up a thread um
and at LinkedIn scale when you have millions of users you have millions of threads starts to cost money um so uh we
try to keep the socket open so we established one connection up and we try to keep that socket Connection open and and communicate over that connection
which actually gives us about a 20 to 30% boost in performance
um another huge Ben benefit is that client developers are actually doing server development so so one of the

two things I really like about it are usually the two biggest complaints about it um the evented part of it actually um

uh you know if I want to do something I spawn up a thread I I do that in the background and then I sort of continue
um moving to an evented model really requires you to to have this concept of
of of sort of responding to events responding to actions responding to something happening and um surprisingly
enough client developers uh are naturally uh attuned for that because
every UI uh framework whether it's native or in the browser is evented by definition forget about the language it
is evented by definition right you are waiting for somebody to click on a button and then you will respond to it
so um for for client developers it's actually been easier for them uh than doing the threaded model and trying to
